channel.title: My first few codes i made in python
channel.description:
I started learning python a few days ago and i wanted to post some of my code its funny but the tutor I'm learning from told me to be creative so here is one python program i made. i would love to know everyone's thoughts or ideas how to improve it.
my code [code]pornstar = 3 people = 12 sad = 7 happy = 5
people = sad - happy pornstar = happy people = happy + sad average = happy / sad
print "there are", people, "happy and sad" print "there are", pornstar, "able to sexytime" print "there are", happy, "but there are too many sad" print "there are", sad, "sadface"[/code]

item.title: My first few codes i made in python
item.dc:creator: @kronixz kronikz
item.description:
@kronixz wrote:

[quote=“zachera, post:10, topic:444876”]I wrote a Tic-Tac-Toe game in Python a while back.[code=python]# tic-tac-toe by zzatkin
import sys,random

board = []
players = []
wins = [[0,1,2],[0,3,6],[0,4,8],[1,4,7],[2,4,6],[2,5,8],[3,4,5],[6,7,8]]

for i in range(0,9):
board.append("-")

def check_for_winner():
for i in range(0,len(wins)):
if board[wins[i][0]] != “-” and board[wins[i][1]] != “-” and board[wins[i][2]] != “-”:
if board[wins[i][0]] == board[wins[i][1]] and board[wins[i][1]] == board[wins[i][2]] and board[wins[i][2]] == board[wins[i][0]]:
print_board()
print board[wins[i][0]] + " has won the game!"
exit(0)

def is_board_full():
for i in range(0,9):
if board[i] == “-”:
return False
return True

def print_board():
for i in range(0,9):
sys.stdout.write(board[i])
if (i + 1) % 3 == 0:
sys.stdout.write("\n")

def start():
print “Player 1: x or o? "
selection = raw_input(”> ")
if selection == “x” or selection == “X”:
players.append(“x”)
players.append(“o”)
print “Okay. Player 2 will be o.”
elif selection == “o” or selection == “O”:
players.append(“o”)
players.append(“x”)
print “Okay. Player 2 will be x.”
else:
print “Okay, I’ll pick for you.”
random_letter = “x” if random.sample([0,1],1) == 0 else “o”
players.append(random_letter)
players.append((“o” if random_letter == “x” else “x”))
print "Player 1 will be " + random_letter + “, and Player 2 will be " + (“o” if random_letter == “x” else “x”) + “.”
print “””
In this tic-tac-toe game, the board is laid out in such a way that you choose which location you want to place your move. This is how the board is defined to be:
012
345
678
So, if you want to place your letter in the top-right corner, you want to type in the number “2” for your selection.

Have fun, and good luck!
“”"
current_player = 0 if random.sample([0,1],1) == 1 else 0
while not is_board_full():
print “Player " + str((current_player + 1)) + “'s (”” + players[current_player] + “”) turn!"
print_board()
valid_input = False
while not valid_input:
location = raw_input("Choose a location: ")
try:
location = int(location)
except:
print “Invalid location. Please try again.”
continue
if location < 0 or 9 <= location:
print “Invalid location. Please try again.”
continue
if board[location] == “x” or board[location] == “o”:
print “That location has already been taken. Please try again.”
continue
board[location] = players[current_player]
valid_input = True
current_player ^= 1
check_for_winner()

start()[/code][/quote]
haha thats freaking awesome.

OT: It’s good for your first time, I hope you get better. Good luck :3

Read full topic
item.source: My first few codes i made in python

item.title: My first few codes i made in python
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

I wrote a Tic-Tac-Toe game in Python a while back.[code=python]# tic-tac-toe by zzatkin
import sys,random

board = []
players = []
wins = [[0,1,2],[0,3,6],[0,4,8],[1,4,7],[2,4,6],[2,5,8],[3,4,5],[6,7,8]]

for i in range(0,9):
board.append("-")

def check_for_winner():
for i in range(0,len(wins)):
if board[wins[i][0]] != “-” and board[wins[i][1]] != “-” and board[wins[i][2]] != “-”:
if board[wins[i][0]] == board[wins[i][1]] and board[wins[i][1]] == board[wins[i][2]] and board[wins[i][2]] == board[wins[i][0]]:
print_board()
print board[wins[i][0]] + " has won the game!"
exit(0)

def is_board_full():
for i in range(0,9):
if board[i] == “-”:
return False
return True

def print_board():
for i in range(0,9):
sys.stdout.write(board[i])
if (i + 1) % 3 == 0:
sys.stdout.write("\n")

def start():
print “Player 1: x or o? "
selection = raw_input(”> ")
if selection == “x” or selection == “X”:
players.append(“x”)
players.append(“o”)
print “Okay. Player 2 will be o.”
elif selection == “o” or selection == “O”:
players.append(“o”)
players.append(“x”)
print “Okay. Player 2 will be x.”
else:
print “Okay, I’ll pick for you.”
random_letter = “x” if random.sample([0,1],1) == 0 else “o”
players.append(random_letter)
players.append((“o” if random_letter == “x” else “x”))
print "Player 1 will be " + random_letter + “, and Player 2 will be " + (“o” if random_letter == “x” else “x”) + “.”
print “””
In this tic-tac-toe game, the board is laid out in such a way that you choose which location you want to place your move. This is how the board is defined to be:
012
345
678
So, if you want to place your letter in the top-right corner, you want to type in the number “2” for your selection.

Have fun, and good luck!
“”"
current_player = 0 if random.sample([0,1],1) == 1 else 0
while not is_board_full():
print “Player " + str((current_player + 1)) + “'s (”” + players[current_player] + “”) turn!"
print_board()
valid_input = False
while not valid_input:
location = raw_input("Choose a location: ")
try:
location = int(location)
except:
print “Invalid location. Please try again.”
continue
if location < 0 or 9 <= location:
print “Invalid location. Please try again.”
continue
if board[location] == “x” or board[location] == “o”:
print “That location has already been taken. Please try again.”
continue
board[location] = players[current_player]
valid_input = True
current_player ^= 1
check_for_winner()

start()[/code]

item.title: My first few codes i made in python
item.dc:creator: @JavaTC JavaTC
item.description:
@JavaTC wrote:

[quote=“Alec_, post:3, topic:444879”][quote author=Omer_ link=topic=547561.msg4015062#msg4015062 date=1339547976]

What the fuck is this??

Shut up.
[/quote]

Why? This is poor practice and he shouldn’t learn from examples like this. Encouraging him to do so would have a negative impact down the road… The fact that the code wouldn’t even work should be enough to prove that…[/quote]
Yeah god forbid people learn any fucking way besides the way I did because mine is the best. Everyone has different ways of thinking, i.e we don’t all learn in the same way.

item.title: My first few codes i made in python
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Deify:

ill edit it, i’m starting another class today hopefully ill have something better to share

python files don’t have to contain classes, they’re called modules. java most likely has poisoned you into thinking everything must be an object (ignoring primitives) and be contained in a class structure (class, interface, enumeration). what you’ve made isn’t a class.

Read full topic

@Deify wrote:

I started learning python a few days ago and i wanted to post some of my code its funny but the tutor I’m learning from told me to be creative so here is one python program i made. i would love to know everyone’s thoughts or ideas how to improve it.

my code

[code]pornstar = 3
people = 12
sad = 7
happy = 5

people = sad - happy
pornstar = happy
people = happy + sad
average = happy / sad

print “there are”, people, “happy and sad”
print “there are”, pornstar, “able to sexytime”
print “there are”, happy, “but there are too many sad”
print “there are”, sad, “sadface”[/code]
